instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2018 with USB-C issues
threads.message:
This 2018 Air came in with liquid damage in the area of the USB-C connector on the logic board. Pins 59 (20V) and 55 (Gnd) on the connector were visibly burnt, and a few nearby caps looked corroded (<CAPACITOR>C6405</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C6416</CAPACITOR>, CC711, <CAPACITOR>C3306</CAPACITOR>). 

After clean-up, USB is now stuck at 5V, drawing 0.08A. PPBUS is at 12.3V. I replaced both CD3215s, and I get all LDO voltages except for <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> when plugging into port B. I replaced the Thunderbolt ROM (<CHIP>U2890</CHIP>) with no change.

The CC lines for port A (<SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CCX</SIGNAL>) are not what I see on a good board, while <SIGNAL>USBC_XB_CCX</SIGNAL> are correct. I checked resistances on the CC lines (in diode mode) and those are fine.

What should I check next to find out why PP1V1 and <SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CCX</SIGNAL> are not working?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2018 with USB-C issues
threads.message:
1V1 BMC LDO only appears on the port where the charger is connected.
You can't get  <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> when connect the charger to <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> port.

Did you test the board with both charger and battery connected?
Do you have S-UEM2 tester?
You may need to change J3300.

Check <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> level.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2018 with USB-C issues
threads.message:
Sorry, I meant to write that I do get <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> when plugging into port B, but not <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> when plugging into port A.

When I have a battery and the charger connected, plugging into port B gives me 20V but 0A. Nothing at all on port A.

No S-UEM2 tester. 

I checked for continuity of the CC signals between board and USB-C receptacle and they check out. So I suspect J3300 is fine.

<SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> is always 0V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2018 with USB-C issues
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> is always 0V"
That is sign of USB-C problems.

Did you change J3300?
You've said had burnt pins...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2018 with USB-C issues
threads.message:
On a good board, <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> only changes from 0 to 1.8V when USB-C switches to 20V, so no surprise there.

I replaced J3300, with no change.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2018 with USB-C issues
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> goes low, no 20V switching possible.
SMC is advised about a problem in USB-C area in this case.

You may have broken trace, or still corroded components.
Compare diode mode readings on J3300 with good board.

BTW, SMC is embedded into T2 chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Air 2018 with USB-C issues
threads.message:
Diode readings of J3300 on this board match a good board exactly. 

I think you're right: there's still an undiscovered corroded component or trace somewhere that's messing things up. I'll keep looking.
